instruction: How were the machine learning models (decision tree, support vector machine, and convolutional neural network) utilized in the study to classify different types of microplastics in farmland soil using hyperspectral imaging technology?
Output:
In the study, three machine learning models, namely decision tree (DT), support vector machine (SVM), and convolutional neural network (CNN), were utilized to classify different types of microplastics (MPs) in farmland soil using hyperspectral imaging technology.

To begin, a total of 600 hyperspectral data were collected from 180 sets of farmland soil samples using a hyperspectral imager in the wavelength range of 369-988 nm. The hyperspectral data were then preprocessed using the Savitzky-Golay (S-G) smoothing filter and mean normalization techniques.

Next, principal component analysis (PCA) was applied to reduce the dimensions of the hyperspectral data and simplify the subsequent model construction. The first three principal components were selected, which accounted for a cumulative contribution rate of 98.37% and contained the main information of the original spectral data.

Finally, the three machine learning models (DT, SVM, and CNN) were established to classify three types of MP polymers in farmland soil, namely polyethylene (PE), polypropylene (PP), and polyvinyl chloride (PVC). The models were trained using the preprocessed hyperspectral data.

instruction: Can hyperspectral imaging technology be considered superior to traditional methods for the rapid screening and classification of microplastics in farmland soil, based on the achieved classification accuracies of the decision tree, support vector machine, and convolutional neural network models?
Output: Yes, hyperspectral imaging technology can be considered superior to traditional methods for the rapid screening and classification of microplastics in farmland soil. This conclusion is based on the achieved classification accuracies of the decision tree (DT), support vector machine (SVM), and convolutional neural network (CNN) models. The classification accuracy of the DT model is 87.9%, while the SVM model achieves a classification accuracy of 85.6%. The CNN model, which is based on the S-G smoothing filter, obtains the best prediction effect with a classification accuracy of 92.6%. This indicates that the hyperspectral imaging technique, when combined with appropriate models, can provide more accurate and efficient classification of microplastics in farmland soil compared to traditional methods.
